item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Nintendo Switch 2 Pro Controller Preorders Are Live
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The first special-edition Nintendo Switch 2 Pro Controller has been revealed, and it's a surprising one. Nintendo is releasing a limited-edition Pro Controller themed around Resident Evil Requiem, the next mainline entry in Capcom's survival horror series. The Resident Evil Requiem Edition Pro Controller is available to preorder for $100 at Best Buy and the Nintendo Store. It launches alongside the game on February 27, 2026.

Nintendo Switch 2 Pro Controller - Resident Evil Requiem

$100

The Resident Evil Requiem Edition of the official Switch 2 Pro Controller is the same shade of black as the standard model. Where it differs is the front faceplate has a fictional newspaper clipping published in Raccoon City.

You can see the words "Resident Evil" running along the top of the controller and "Requiem" right below it. Excerpts from articles published in the paper and photographs of the bleak situation on the ground are also pictured. It's a pretty cool design, even if it is somewhat understated due to the lack of contrasting colors.

The Resident Evil Requiem Edition is 10 bucks more than the standard Switch 2 Pro Controller, which is a fairly common price bump for a themed first-party controller.

Switch 2 owners can preorder two different physical editions of Requiem, both of which are limited edition and cost $90. The Resident Evil Generation Pack comes with Requiem, Resident Evil Village Gold Edition, and Resident Evil 7 Gold Edition. The Resident Evil Deluxe Edition comes with a steelbook case, lenticular card, and a bunch of digital content. Check out GameSpot's Resident Evil Requiem preorder guide for more details.

Nintendo will also release a Switch 2 Amiibo for Requiem's protagonist Grace Ashcroft. We don't know what the figure looks like or its price, but Street Fighter 6 Amiibo retail for $40, so that seems like a distinct possibility for the Grace Ashcroft Amiibo. Unfortunately, the Amiibo won't be available at launch, and it currently has a vague Summer 2026 launch window.

item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Preorders: Deluxe Steelbook, Switch 2 Collection, And More
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Resident Evil Requiem preorders are starting to go live at major retailers, and there are multiple cool physical editions as well as themed first-party accessories in the works for the survival horror game's February 27, 2026 launch. Requiem is getting a $90 Deluxe Steelbook Edition for PS5, Xbox, Switch 2, and PC. For the standard $70 base game, the Amazon Exclusive Edition comes with a double-sided poster.

Nintendo Switch 2 owners will also be able to get Requiem, Resident Evil 7, and Resident Evil Village in one bundle called Resident Evil Generation Pack for $90. Village and RE7--and their DLC packs--launch on Switch 2 the same day as Requiem. Switch 2 owners will be able to play all three with a special-edition Resident Evil Switch 2 Pro Controller. Unless Nintendo surprises us before February, Resident Evil Requiem will be the first themed Switch 2 Pro Controller. The Pro Controller will be available on launch day and will be followed by a Grace Ashcroft Amiibo next summer.

Resident Evil Requiem Preorder Bonuses

The Amazon Exclusive Edition comes with the double-sided poster shown above featuring the key art and title on one side and a landscape screenshot on the other. GameStop is giving away an exclusive tote bag, but you'll need to pick up your preorder on launch day (likely at midnight).

All physical and digital preorders come with an in-game costume for Grace called Apocalypse. Check out the physical editions and the official Switch 2 Pro Controller below.

Note: Not all editions are available to preorder at the time of writing, so check back if you aren't able to place your order for the edition you want.

Resident Evil Requiem

$70

Resident Evil Requiem's $70 physical edition will launch on PS5, Xbox Series X, and Nintendo Switch 2. The Amazon Exclusive Edition is available to preorder on both platforms. GameStop is also taking preorders for PlayStation 5 and Xbox, and Best Buy has preorders for all three console platforms.

Resident Evil Requiem Deluxe Steelbook Edition

$90

The $90 Deluxe Edition is for PS5, Xbox Series X, Nintendo Switch 2, and PC (Steam key). It comes with the limited-edition steelbook case featuring a gun on the front and a Raccoon City newspaper clipping on the back. You'll also get a limited-edition lenticular card featuring the game's key art and the police building. Along with the physical extras, the Deluxe Edition comes with numerous digital bonuses.

Here's the full list:

  • Steelbook Case
  • Lenticular Card
  • 5 Costumes
  • 4 Weapon Skins
  • 2 Charms
  • Audio Pack: Raccoon City Classic
  • Files: Letters from 1998
  • Screen Filter: Apocalypse

Resident Evil Generation Pack for Switch 2

$90

The Resident Evil Generation Pack appears to be exclusive to Nintendo Switch 2 in the US. In Japan, it will be available on Switch 2 and PS5. This is a limited release that will also be sold digitally but only until March 31, 2026.

The Generation Pack comes with Requiem, Resident Evil Village Gold Edition, and Resident 7 Biohazard Gold Edition. All three titles are Game-Key Cards on Switch 2 and will be packaged in their own standard cases. The Generation Pack comes with an oversized display box with the Resident Evil 30th Anniversary logo on the side. The front of the display box has "Resident Evil Generation Pack" on what appears to be a tombstone.

item.title: Take-Two CEO Doesn't Believe AI Can Compete With Grand Theft Auto
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The age of AI has barely begun, but there are some in the industry who see it as an absolute necessity for the future. Electronic Arts, for example, has reportedly instructed its employees to treat AI as "thought partners" in every aspect of game creation. However, Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick isn't buying into the hype, and he doesn't believe AI will ever be able to compete with Rockstar Games' Grand Theft Auto games.

"Let's say there were no constraints [on AI]," said Zelnick during an appearance on CNBC. "Could we push a button tomorrow and create an equivalent to the Grand Theft Auto marketing plan? The answer is no. A, you can't do that yet, and B, I am of the view that you wouldn't end up with anything very good. You end up with something pretty derivative."

Zelnick went on to explain that AI can't innovate, because it's "backward-looking" by design and its predictive models are built on things that have already been created, rather than anything new.

This isn't the first time Zelnick has shared his feelings about AI, and he's been fairly consistent over the years. Earlier this month, Zelnick made a point of saying that people overstate what AI can do.

Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer recently disclosed that his company primarily uses AI for security purposes, but he didn't rule out its role in game creation. Meanwhile, Microsoft is attempting to fully integrate AI and voice commands into Windows 11 machines. Video game developers Hideo Kojima and Glen Schofield have both stated that AI tools should be embraced in game creation. A recent survey also found that over 50% of Japanese game publishers utilize AI in some way.

item.title: Runescape's Future May Be Radically Reshaped After Fan Vote
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The daily Treasure Hunter has been a part of Runescape since 2014, and some of the game's players openly resent it as a pay-to-win feature that diminishes the experience for fans who don't utilize it. Jagex has been exploring its options for the feature, and now the developer is leaving Treasure Hunter's fate in the hands of the fans.

Jagex has started an online poll that will determine if Treasure Hunter will stay in Runescape. If 100,000 players vote to remove Treasure Hunter, it will be completely deleted from the game alongside 225 direct XP and skilling items that are related to it. That would leave the game with only two purchasable items: Bonus XP with capped storable limits per skill and cosmetics "with a more grounded visual identity."

"Today marks one of the most important moments in Runescape history," reads a statement on the site. "We are proposing a new future for the game led by integrity, where your achievements are based on merit, and the vast experiences offered within Gielinor can truly shine.This is an era-defining shift for Runescape where YOU will cast the deciding vote--just as we did for the birth of Old School."

Jagex has previously laid out the results of its experiments with Treasure Hunter, and earlier polling that indicated it was a valuable resource for "time-poor" players. To appeal to those players, Bonus XP will remain in the store, but the new skill caps for storable XP are meant to encourage players to engage in the regular gameplay rather than simply buying all of their experience.

If the vote goes forward to remove Treasure Hunter, Jagex stated that it will "invest in a year-long Integrity Roadmap that addresses the heart of issues that have long held Runescape back--from UI, to onboarding, to dailyscape, revisiting the combat status quo and beyond. We'll also be looking at the balance of our XP progression too, ensuring each skill is still a satisfying experience to level up with a significant reduction in MTX-relative skilling items."

To place a vote, players will have to be logged in as their Runescape characters. The voting period will run until November 12, and nearly 40,000 players have already voted in favor of removing Treasure Hunter.

Outside of the main game, Old School Runescape recently broke its concurrent-user record with 241,016 players.
